introduction.p: In this activity, we will explore polynomial functions by building on our knowledge of linear and power functions.
A polynomial is a function of the form f(x) = a_0 + a_1 x + a_2 x^2 + \cdots + a_n x^n where the numbers a_0 through a_n are constant values.
The degree of a polynomial is the highest exponent on the variable.

example.p: Some polynomial functions and their degrees:

introduction.p: A root of a polynomial is a value of the input which gives an output of zero.

example.p: The value x = -2.5 is a root for the function f(x) = 6x^2 + 7x - 20 because: f(-2.5) \amp= 6(-2.5)^2 + 7(-2.5) - 20 \amp= 37.5 - 17.5 - 20 \amp= 0

statement.p: What is the degree of the polynomial f(x) = x + ?
Answer:
Find the root of the function f(x) = x + .
Answer: =

introduction.p: Now, we will see how our knowledge of first degree polynomials ("lines") will help us to understand polynomials of higher and higher degrees.

statement.p: [@MODES(HTML=>'<iframe scrolling="no" src="https://www.geogebra.org/material/iframe/id/ZQ4DEqee/width/432/height/373/border/888888" width="432px" height="373px" style="border:0px;"> </iframe>', TeX =>"A GeoGebra applet.");@]*
The 2^{nd} degree polynomial y = (x - 2)(x + 1) is the product of two linear functions: y = x - 2 \text{ and } y = x + 1
The 1^{st} degree polynomials each had one root. Where are the roots of the 2^{nd} degree polynomial?
Answer:

solution.p: If a function p is the product of two linear functions f and g, then p will have both the roots of the f and g.

set.member: \text{All the roots of f, g and h}
\text{None of the roots of f, g or h}

introduction.p: By now, you are already seeing a relationship between the roots of a polynomial, and the roots of its linear factors.
Use this observation to make predictions about the graph of a polynomial in the next exercise.

statement.p: Thinking about the linear factors of p as lines, each with its own root, choose which option below could be the graph of p(x).

hint.p: If you take each of the factors as a linear function y = x - 2 y = x + 1 y = 2x - 6 and find the root of each one, this will tell you where the function p(x) should cross the x-axis.

solution.p: The graph of p(x) = (x-2)(x+1))2x-6) is graph because it has the roots x = 2 x = -1 x = 3

introduction.p: In the next two problems, you'll guess the number of roots of a polynomial and where those roots are located.

introduction.p: Now, let's summarize what we've seen up to this point in the next exercise.

statement.p: Complete each statement below:
If a polynomial is the product of N different linear factors, then its graph will have different x-intercepts.
The degree of such a polynomial is equal to the number of its
For each linear factor x - a, the polynomial will have an x-intercept at the point

solution.p: If a polynomial has a factor of (x - a), then evaluating that polynomial the value x = a will give it a factor of zero. This will make zero the output of the polynomial, so its graph will contain the point (a,0).

introduction.p: One important note should be made here: Not every polynomial can be written as just a product of linear factors (the function f(x) = x^2 + 1 is an easy example, as it has no x-intercepts).
But in this section, we will focus primarily on polynomials which can be written as a product of linear factors.

One skill we will develop here is being able to determine a formula for a polynomial if we have its graph. However, before we can do that, we need to discuss the end-behavior of a polynomial — that is, the function's behavior as x gets far from zero. This is one thing we can tell about the graph of a polynomial, even if it is not written as a product of linear factors, such as: y = 3x - 5x^2 + 17 \text{or} y = -950x + x^3
Pause here for an activity which concerns the end-behavior of a polynomial.
We have now learned the two important things we need in order to write the formula for a polynomial:
introduction.blockquote: the relationship between the roots of a polynomial and its linear factors
the relationship between the end-behavior of a polynomial and its leading term
introduction.p: Let's put these together in order to write the formula for a polynomial.
In the next two exercises, you will be given the graph of a polynomial. Use what you know about the roots and end-behavior in order to write the formula.

statement.p: A polynomial y = f(x) is graphed below. Your goal is to write its formula.

[@MODES(HTML=>'<iframe scrolling="no" src="https://www.geogebra.org/material/iframe/id/f2vXupVA/width/425/height/373/border/888888" width="425px" height="373px" style="border:0px;"> </iframe>', TeX =>"A GeoGebra applet.");@]*
Complete the statement with a number:
The polynomial will have different linear factors.
Now write the formula for the polynomial:

hint.p: Remember that if a polynomial has an x-intercept at the point (b, 0), then it will have a linear factor of (x - b).
Apply this idea to each of the linear factors.

solution.p: The x-intercepts are at the points: (-1, 0) (2, 0) (3, 0)
So, the formula will have the linear factors: (x + 1) (x - 2) (x - 3)

statement.p: The graph below shows a polynomial y = f(x). Answer the following questions in order to write the formula for f(x).

[@MODES(HTML=>'<iframe scrolling="no" src="https://www.geogebra.org/material/iframe/id/y8BaH6kM/width/425/height/373/border/888888" width="425px" height="373px" style="border:0px;"> </iframe>', TeX =>"A GeoGebra applet.");@]*
The x-intercept (-4, 0) means the formula will have a linear factor of:
The x-intercept (-1, 0) means the formula will have a linear factor of:
The x-intercept (2, 0) means the formula will have a linear factor of:
The end-behavior of the polynomial is the same as
Now put all of these together in order to write the formula for the polynomial:

hint.p: Notice the end-behavior looks like -x^3. Remember to incorporate that into your final formula. One idea is to just put a negative symbol outside of the parentheses (like multiplying it all by -1).

solution.p: Each x-intercept corresponds to a linear factor in the formula: (-4, 0) \amp\implies (x + 4) (-1, 0) \amp\implies (x + 1) (2, 0) \amp\implies (x - 2)
Also, the end-behavior is the same as -x^3, so our graph needs to be flipped over the x-axis.
We can test that our formula works by using the point (0, 8) shown: f(0) \amp= -(0 + 4)(0 + 1)(0 - 2) \amp=8
